SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: What does paragraph 5 reveal about Paige?

A.Choice: She fears going out on the lake.

B.Choice: She wants to avoid her grandparents.

C.Choice: She prefers the outdoors to coming inside.

D.Choice: She wants to play with the neighborhood girls.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: How do paragraphs 8 through 10 develop the plot of the story?

A.Choice: They give background information about Paige.

B.Choice: They illustrate Paige's internal conflict.

C.Choice: They explain why Paige admires her Grandpa.

D.Choice: They show how Paige and her brothers are alike.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 14 below.
:box:Across from the kitchenette stood the bathroom, which contributed to the monster's bad case of morning breath.
What does the metaphor mean in the sentence?

A.Choice: The RV had a rotten smell.

B.Choice: People slept poorly inside the RV.

C.Choice: The RV was a cramped place.

D.Choice: People made a mess inside the RV.

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: Which detail signlas a change in the direction of the story?

A.Choice: Grandpa loans Paige a fishing pole.

B.Choice: Paige warns her family about the heat.

C.Choice: Grandpa and Grandma arrive in their RV.

D.Choice: Paige and the girls beat the boys in a water fight.

SubTopics: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.
Content: How does the atuhor most develop Grandpa's point of view in the story?

A.Choice: by having the narrator describe Grandpa

B.Choice: by sharing Grandpa's thoughts with the reader

C.Choice: by including dialogue between Grandpa and the kids

D.Choice: by showing how Grandpa acts with Paige's brothers

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which detail would be most important to include in a summary of the story?

A.Choice: Paige loses a lot of fishing poles.

B.Choice: Grandpa owns many different hats.

C.Choice: Paige enjoys water-skiing and tubing.

D.Choice: Grandpa wants to take the kids fishing.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which sentence best expresses the theme of the story?

A.Choice: People usually change as they grow older.

B.Choice: Sometimes people are embarrassed by family.

C.Choice: People often cherish their childhood memories.

D.Choice: Sometimes people make choices to please others.

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: How do paragraphs 3 and 4 contribute to the story?

A.Choice: They help show Rakhee's kindness and ease around creatures in the outdoors.

B.Choice: They help the reader understand Rakhee's concern of whether her grandmother will remember her.

C.Choice: They provide evidence for Rakhee's love of singing Indian songs as a child.

D.Choice: They give the reader insight into Rakhee's memories of her grandmother.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which important idea does the author develop in paragraphs 7 through 9?

A.Choice: Rakhee has lived a very exciting life.

B.Choice: Rakhee wishes she had grown up in India.

C.Choice: Rakhee has much to learn about her family's culture.

D.Choice: Rakhee's family is typical of Indian families.

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: Which statement best describes how the narrator reacts to the events in paragraphs 8 and 9?

A.Choice: She becomes more appreciative of her mother.

B.Choice: She is uneasy about the change in her mother.

C.Choice: She becomes confused by her mother.

D.Choice: She admires the change in her mother.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: In paragraph 9, what is the meaning of the phrase “it streamed down her back in a lustrous river”?

A.Choice: her long hair was flowing and shiny

B.Choice: her long hair was damp from being in a bun

C.Choice: her long hair seemed heavier than normal

D.Choice: her long hair moved steadily in one direction

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: What does paragraph 9 most reveal about the narrator's mother?

A.Choice: that she is more talkative when she is in India

B.Choice: that she follows customary traditions when she is in India

C.Choice: that she is more self-conscious when she is in India

D.Choice: that she visits many people when she is in India

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which statement best states a theme of the story?

A.Choice: Families can be surprising.

B.Choice: Beauty can be found in most things.

C.Choice: Traveling to new places can be tiring.

D.Choice: New experiences can change how we see the world.

SubTopics: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.
Content: How does the author most develop Rakhee's point of view?

A.Choice: by comparing Rakhee's experience to her mother's

B.Choice: by having Rakehee describe her impressions of India

C.Choice: by showing Rakhee's alarm during the scene with the elephant

D.Choice: by including Rakhee's reaction to Amma's changed appearance

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: How is the idea “Lightning begins inside thunderstorms” (paragraph 2) developed in the article?

A.Choice: by comparing a lightning bolt to a small spark

B.Choice: by describing how lightning occurs in different types of weather

C.Choice: by explaining how air at different temperatures creates a charge in clouds

D.Choice: by providing examples of how much electricity is produced by electrons jumping through air

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings.
Content: Read this quotation from paragraph 6.
:box:Between 1,500 and 2,000 thunderstorms are crackling and booming around the world at this very moment ...
Why does the author use the words “crackling and booming” instead of “occuring”?

A.Choice: to help the reader experience the speed of lightning

B.Choice: the help the reader imagine the sounds of thunderstorms

C.Choice: to be clear about the electrical nature of lightning

D.Choice: to be accurate about how  common thunderstorms are

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Integrate information presented in different media or formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively) as well as in words to develop a coherent understanding of a topic or issue.
Content: How does the illustration support the author's claims in the section “Lightning around the World”?

A.Choice: by highlighting the size of lightning strikes in particular areas

B.Choice: by providing evidence of why lightning strikes in some areas

C.Choice: by illustrating which areas are more affected by lightning strikes

D.Choice: by showing the limited areas in the world where lightning strikes occur

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
Content: How does the section “Lightning Safety” connect to the section “What is Lightning?”

A.Choice: “Lightning Safety” summarizes the effects of lightning described in “What is Lightning?”

B.Choice: “Lightning Safety” contrasts different types of lightning described in “What is Lightning?”

C.Choice: “Lightning Safety” elaborates on the cause of the powerful lightning described in “What is Lightning?”

D.Choice: “Lightning Safety” describes ways to avoid the powerful lightning explained in “What is Lightning?”

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which sentence best expresses a central idea in the article?

A.Choice: Lightning strikes are only about as thick as a pencil.

B.Choice: Lightning strikes are uncommon far out over the ocean.

C.Choice: Lightning strikes are due to unstable weather conditions.

D.Choice: Lightning strikes are able to travel through pipes in a building.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: What does paragraph 9 suggest about the author's point of view in the article?

A.Choice: The author has great respect for lightning.

B.Choice: The author has difficulty understanding lightning.

C.Choice: The author believes that lightning can be useful.

D.Choice: The author believes that it is impossible to avoid lightning.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which idea would be most important to include in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: “The farther away lightning strikes, the deeper the sound of the thunder ...” (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: “Lightning zaps the remote mountain village of Kifuka, in central Africa, nearly every day.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “Because of its unpredictability and power, lightning can be extremely dangerous.” (paragraph 8)

D.Choice: “You're safe inside the car because electricity will travel over the metal surface instead of through the interior.” (paragraph 9)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 6.
:box:Urashima never grew tired, nor his clothes moist from the water.
What effect does the sentence have on the tone of the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.
Content: How does paragraph 15 help develop Urashima's point of view? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 16.
:box:“Yesterday you set free a tortoise, and I have sent for you to thank you for saving my life, for I was that tortoise.”
How does this sentence contribute to the structure of the story? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: In “The Thirst for First Is the Worst,” how do paragraphs 1 through 4 develop a central idea of the article? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: In “The Thirst for First Is the Worst,” how was the author affected by attemptintg to become more compettive? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: What is the central idea of “[Excerpt from] The Importance of Winning”? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Content: The authors of “The Thirst for First Is the Worst” and “[Excerpt from] The Importance of Winning” have different opinions about whether athletes should be committed to winning. What are the authors' different points of view about this topic? How is this point of view revelead in each article? Use details from both articles to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• describe the authors' different opinions about whether athletes should be committed to winning
• explain how this point of view is revealed in each article
• use details from both articles to support your response
